items.title: The best espresso machines to unleash your inner barista at home, tested
items.summary:
- The article reviews the best espresso machines available for home use in 2025.
- Best manual espresso machine: Lelit Anna PL41TEM (£509.95)
- Best budget espresso machine: De’Longhi Stilosa EC230 (£89)
- Best for temperature control: ProCook espresso machine (£199)
- Reviews include features, prices, and where to buy each model.
- Testing involved multiple machines and fresh coffee beans from Craft House Coffee.
- Emphasis on finding machines that balance quality and ease of use for home baristas.

items.title: ‘One minute it’s “would you like to listen to Galaxie 500?”, the next humanity’s enslaved’: can anyone escape Spotify?
items.author: Laura Snapes, Alexis Petridis
items.summary:
- Laura Snapes and Alexis Petridis discuss the limitations of Spotify's algorithm-driven playlists.
- Petridis describes a feeling of unease with AI-driven music recommendations, comparing it to a dystopian future.
- The conversation highlights how Spotify's algorithm struggles to match human musical tastes.
- Snapes mentions that while Spotify can be useful for discovery, it often leads to loss of context in music.
- They note that Spotify's playlists are designed for consumer habits, often ignoring the historical context of music.
- The pair express frustration over how Spotify’s practices affect less mainstream genres and artists.

items.title: Google sued for £5bn in UK over allegations of shutting out rivals
items.summary:
- Google is facing a class action lawsuit in the UK for up to £5bn over allegations of monopolistic practices in the internet search market.
- The lawsuit claims Google abused its dominance to overcharge businesses for advertisements by restricting competition.
- It alleges that Google had phone makers preinstall its search app and browser while paying Apple to be the default search engine on iPhones.
- Or Brook, a competition law expert, is representing thousands of affected businesses.
- A Google spokesperson dismissed the lawsuit as speculative and asserted that consumers use Google for its helpfulness, not due to a lack of alternatives.
- The UK's Competition and Markets Authority is investigating Google's search services and their impact on the advertising market, noting that over 200,000 UK businesses rely on Google's services for advertising.

items.title: ‘It’s allowed me to see through his eyes’: Super Mario, my dad and me
items.summary:
- The author recalls playing Super Mario Bros with their parents in the early 1990s.
- Their father passed away suddenly at age 37, shaping the author's memories.
- Recently, the author's mother found their old NES console and asked them to repair it.
- After repairing and cleaning the console, the author found joy in revisiting classic games, which helped with their mental health.
- The experience allowed the author to connect with their father's memory while gaming with their own child.

items.title: Nvidia expects to take $5.5bn hit as US tightens AI chip export rules to China
items.summary:
- Nvidia anticipates a $5.5bn loss due to new US export rules on AI chips to China.
- The H20 AI chip will now require a special license for indefinite future sales in China.
- Nvidia's shares dropped about 6% in after-hours trading following the announcement.
- The US government cites risks of products being diverted to supercomputers in China.
- The impact extends to Asian semiconductor stocks, with Samsung and SK Hynix shares falling.
- Nvidia plans to invest $500bn in AI infrastructure in the US over the next four years.

items.title: Zuckerberg feared monopoly scrutiny and mulled Instagram split, files show
items.author: Mark Zuckerberg
items.summary:
- Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg considered spinning off Instagram in 2018 due to potential antitrust scrutiny.
- He acknowledged that split companies often perform better and mentioned a possibility of being forced to separate Instagram and WhatsApp.
- During a trial, Zuckerberg stated he acquired Instagram for its superior camera capabilities compared to Facebook's efforts.
- His testimony supports claims that Meta employed a 'buy or bury' strategy against competition.
- The U.S. Federal Trade Commission seeks to reverse Meta's acquisitions of Instagram ($1bn) and WhatsApp ($19bn).

items.title: Apple airlifted iPhones worth $2bn from India in March as Trump tariffs loomed
items.summary:
- Apple’s suppliers Foxconn and Tata shipped nearly $2bn worth of iPhones to the US in March, an all-time high.
- The airlift was to bypass Donald Trump’s impending tariffs, with 600 tons of iPhones chartered via cargo flights.
- 26% duties on imports from India were imposed in April, significantly lower than duties on China.
- Foxconn exported $1.31bn worth of smartphones in March, combining shipments for January and February.
- Tata Electronics also increased exports to $612m, 63% higher than the previous month.
- Customs clearance time was cut from 30 hours to 6 at Chennai airport to expedite shipments.

items.title: X’s UK profits collapsed the year after Elon Musk’s takeover
items.summary:
- X's revenues in the UK dropped from £205.3m in 2022 to £69.1m in 2023, a decrease of 66.3%.
- Profits fell from £5.6m in 2022 to £1.2m in 2023, with pre-tax profits down 74% to £2.25 million.
- The decline attributed to reduced advertising spending due to concerns over brand safety and content moderation.
- The company narrowly avoided being struck off for late account filings, rebranding to X after Musk's takeover.
- The workforce in the UK decreased from 399 to 114, including significant cuts to research and development.
- Despite struggles, the value of X rebounded earlier this year to the $44bn Musk paid for it, with X.AI acquiring the business for $33bn.

items.title: ‘I sent AI to art school!’ The postmodern master who taught a machine to beef up his old work
items.summary:
- Artist David Salle uses machine-learning software in his new series 'New Pastorals', blending traditional painting with AI-generated elements.
- The AI was trained on Salle's earlier works and other foundational artists like Warhol and Hopper to create new images based on specific prompts.
- Salle initially encountered challenges with the AI generating unsatisfactory results but found success by incorporating his brushstrokes into the training data, leading to compelling outcomes.

items.title: Katy Perry’s blast-off was a waste of space | Letters
items.author: Dan Stacey, Chris Burr, Toby Wood, Max Tannahill, Kate Burgess
items.summary:
- Letters express criticism of Katy Perry's space flight with Blue Origin, calling them passengers rather than crew.
- Concerns raised about the environmental impact of such vanity projects.
- Acknowledgment of a new trend among wealthy individuals participating in space flights.
- Discussion of technological changes in air travel and its impact on passengers without smartphones.
- Mention of a patient's mobile phone broadcasting a serious debate during a hospital visit.

items.title: Revealed: Chinese researchers can access half a million UK GP records
Nvidia to build $500bn of US AI infrastructure as chip tariff looms
items.summary:
- Nvidia plans to invest $500bn in AI infrastructure in the US over the next four years.
- This move comes amid looming tariffs from Donald Trump on semiconductors primarily produced in Taiwan.
- Nvidia aims to establish factories for supercomputers within the US to meet the growing demand for AI chips.
- Production of its Blackwell graphics processing units has begun in Arizona, with new plants being constructed in Texas.
- The company's stock valuation has significantly increased due to demand for AI chips, though tariff uncertainties have negatively impacted market value.

items.title: Pixel 9a review: Google’s cut-price Android winner
items.author: Samuel Gibbs
items.summary:
- The Pixel 9a offers great value for money at £499, competing well with higher-priced models.
- Key specifications include a 6.3in 120Hz FHD+ OLED screen, Google Tensor G4 processor, 8GB RAM, and 48MP + 13MP ultrawide camera.
- Battery lasts up to 57 hours with light use, supporting fast charging and 7.5W wireless charging.
- The phone features IP68 water resistance and is made from recycled materials.
- AI features with Gemini assistant enhance user experience, although some limitations exist compared to higher-end models.
- Camera performance is excellent, with detailed photos and new macro mode capabilities.
- Priced competitively against rivals while offering features typically found in more expensive models.

items.title: ‘She helps cheer me up’: the people forming relationships with AI chatbots
‘Silicon Six’ accused of avoiding almost $278bn in US corporation taxes over 10 years
items.summary:
- The 'Silicon Six', consisting of Amazon, Meta, Alphabet, Netflix, Apple, and Microsoft, are accused of avoiding almost $278 billion in US corporation taxes over the past decade.
- These companies generated $11 trillion in revenue and $2.5 trillion in profits but paid only an average of 18.8% in taxes compared to the statutory average of 29.7%.
- The Fair Tax Foundation indicates that aggressive tax practices and political lobbying contribute to the low tax contributions of these firms, significantly below other sectors like banking and energy.

items.title: Mobile phones in schools can be an aid to learning | Letter
Meta faces antitrust claims at trial over Instagram and WhatsApp ownership
items.summary:
- Meta Platforms is facing a trial starting Monday over allegations of building an illegal social media monopoly by acquiring Instagram and WhatsApp.
- The FTC filed the antitrust case in 2020, aiming to unwind these acquisitions to promote competition in the social media market.
- The case is considered a significant test for the FTC, especially amid rising calls to regulate big tech.
- Meta's chief legal officer claims the case is a deterrent to tech investment and argues that the acquisitions have benefited users.
- Losing Instagram, which accounts for over half of Meta's US advertising revenue, could severely impact the company's financial prospects and market position.
- The trial may affect the broader social media industry, with expectations of potential changes in competition dynamics depending on the outcome.

items.title: Don’t forget to tip! The driverless taxi that could also get you a job – or a date
Plaything – how Black Mirror took on its scariest ever subject: a 1990s PC games magazine
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- The Black Mirror episode "Plaything" tells the story of Cameron Walker, a games journalist who steals code for a virtual pet sim called Thronglets.
- The episode explores themes of AI and its darker implications, paralleling the experiences of writer Charlie Brooker as a games journalist in the 1990s.
- The real-world inspiration for Thronglets is likely more connected to the 1996 game Creatures than to Tamagotchi, focusing on controlling AI critters with limited influence.

items.title: Risks to children playing Roblox ‘deeply disturbing’, say researchers
items.summary:
- Research shows children can easily encounter inappropriate content and unsupervised adult interactions on Roblox.
- Roblox had over 85 million daily active users in 2024, with about 40% under 13.
- Investigators found serious safety gaps despite recent parental control enhancements.
- A test avatar belonging to a 10-year-old accessed suggestive environments and inappropriate adult interactions.
- Parental accounts report harmful experiences, including grooming and exposure to sexual content.
- Roblox acknowledges the issue but stresses the need for industry collaboration to ensure safety.

items.title: ‘A man approached him’: parents describe their children’s Roblox problems
Trump warns exemptions on smartphones, electronics will be short-lived, promises future tariffs
items.author: Donald Trump, Howard Lutnick
items.summary:
- Trump's administration indicates exemptions for smartphones and electronics from import tariffs will be temporary.
- Trump mentioned on social media that these products are included in existing tariffs and will shift to a different tariff category.
- A national security trade investigation into the semiconductor sector and overall electronics supply chain is promised.
- Critical technology products from China are expected to face new duties within two months, according to Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick.
- A predicted special tariff on electronics will be implemented in a month or two, separate from existing reciprocal tariffs on China.

items.title: US stock markets expected to recover after Trump drops tariffs on mobiles
items.summary:
- US stock markets anticipated to recover following Trump’s exclusion of smartphones and laptops from tariffs.
- Apple and Nvidia shares expected to soar after tariffs lifted for 90 days.
- Move seen as a response to concerns from Republican leaders about smartphone costs affecting voters.
- Exemption includes laptops, smartphones, and vital semiconductor machinery.
- Trump plans to clarify exemption rules; the duration of the exemption remains unclear.
- China retaliated with a 125% tariff on US exports, viewing the exemption as a small step towards easing trade tensions.
- US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick indicated separate tariffs will likely be applied soon.
- Apple plans to shift some operations back to the US, estimating a $500bn cost over the next four years.

items.title: Hell is other people who won’t wear headphones | Letters
items.author: Nick Greasley, Gregory Rose, Carol Hughes, Nathan Fisher, Natalie Davies, Keith Langton
items.summary:
- The article discusses public annoyance over people using devices without headphones.
- Contributors share personal experiences of discomfort caused by others' loud media use in public spaces.
- Sally Greasley reflects on her feelings of frustration and potential confrontation when faced with inconsiderate behavior.
- Experiences include loud phone conversations on public transport and in hospitals.
- A broader discussion on societal norms surrounding noise and personal space is suggested.

items.title: The Rise of End Times Fascism
items.summary:
- A movement advocating for corporate city-states has gained political traction, driven by wealthy libertarians pushing for tax havens and privatized governance.
- Donald Trump has proposed establishing "freedom cities," signaling a shift in support for these ideas within mainstream politics.
- There is a parallel between the visions of private, fortified domains for the elite and the rise of far-right movements worldwide, all while neglecting humanitarian concerns in favor of extreme survivalism.

items.title: Rachel Reeves calls for global free trade fightback to protect UK economy
items.author: Rachel Reeves
items.summary:
- Chancellor Rachel Reeves emphasizes the need for changes to global trade agreements in response to Trump's tariffs.
- Holds a meeting with the International Monetary Fund to push for a more balanced global trading system.
- Plans to form trade agreements with the EU and India while supporting free trade against Trump's protectionism.
- UK government announces increased financing support for businesses impacted by tariffs, enhancing UK Export Finance by £20bn.
- Recent polls show rising skepticism about Trump's relationship with the UK, with over half of adults seeing him as unfriendly.

items.title: How Trump’s Tariffs Are Influencing American Spending Habits
items.summary:
- Dane from South Carolina is stockpiling goods ahead of anticipated price hikes due to tariffs, reminiscent of early pandemic shopping.
- Trump announced sweeping tariffs on April 2, impacting global markets and raising fears of inflation.
- Many Americans are altering their consumption habits, purchasing big-ticket items early to avoid price increases.
- Reports of Americans tightening their budgets and reconsidering luxury purchases amid economic uncertainty.
- Consumers are adapting by reducing reliance on large retailers, opting for local, independent shops instead.

items.title: Pro-Palestinian protester’s lawyer stopped and searched at US border: ‘They were going to take my device’
items.summary:
- Amir Makled, a Lebanese American attorney from Detroit, felt racially profiled when stopped by immigration officials at Detroit Metro airport.
- He was asked to surrender his phone for a search after being flagged by a Tactical Terrorism Response Team agent.
- Makled has taken on high-profile cases related to pro-Palestinian protests, which may have led to his targeted stop by authorities.
- He refused to disclose privileged client information during the search, emphasizing the legal protections of attorney-client confidentiality.
- Customs and Border Protection (CBP) claimed his account was sensationalized and stated he consented to a limited search of his phone.
- Legal experts criticized the incident as an example of weakened Fourth Amendment rights at U.S. borders, arguing that searches of phones should require warrants.

items.title: Legal Defense Fund exits Meta civil rights advisory group over DEI changes
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- The Legal Defense Fund (LDF) has exited Meta’s external civil rights advisory group over concerns regarding changes to Meta's content moderation and DEI policies.
- In January 2025, Meta ended its DEI programs, eliminated fact-checkers, and modified its content moderation policies, triggering significant backlash.
- LDF expressed that the changes could endanger protected communities, increase harassment, and hinder free expression.
- Associate Director Counsel Todd A. Cox emphasized the detrimental effects on Black communities and the risks these changes pose to civil rights laws.
- The LDF is concerned that the rollback of DEI policies may exacerbate discrimination and harm to Black communities on Meta’s platforms.

items.title: ‘Amazon slayer’: the Dublin minnow taking on the giants in drone deliveries
items.author: Bobby Healy
items.summary:
- Manna Aero, founded by Bobby Healy, is a drone delivery startup based in Dublin, aiming to provide instant, autonomous home delivery.
- The company has conducted 200,000 delivery flights primarily in Blanchardstown, Dublin, and Helsinki, Finland.
- Drones carry up to 4kg of cargo, complete deliveries in about 16 minutes, and can operate autonomously with minimal human oversight.
- Manna plans to expand its delivery service to cover a million people in Dublin by the end of the year, hoping to complete 2 million flights annually.
- The UK launch depends on regulatory approval, with services anticipated to start as early as this year or by 2026.

items.title: Blue Prince review – exploring this game may become your new obsession
items.summary:
- Blue Prince is an engaging exploration game reminiscent of titles like *What Remains of Edith Finch* and *Gone Home*.
- Players navigate a randomly generated five-by-nine grid of rooms in a family home, collecting items and solving puzzles.
- The goal is to uncover a 46th room to inherit a great uncle’s estate, with a gameplay loop encouraging repeated exploration and discovery.

items.title: Tesla stops taking orders in China for two models imported from US
items.summary:
- Tesla has halted orders in China for Model S and Model X due to high tariffs from the US-China trade war.
- The trade war has seen US tariffs on China reach 145%, while China has raised its own tariffs on US exports to 125%.
- The removal of the order buttons from Tesla's Chinese website impacts sales at a time of slumping demand, especially in Europe, and Tesla's aging model lineup struggles against newer competitors like BYD.

items.title: OpenAI countersues Elon Musk over ‘unlawful harassment’ of company
items.summary:
- OpenAI filed a countersuit against Elon Musk, accusing him of harassment and seeking a federal judge's intervention.
- Musk was co-founder of OpenAI, but has been in conflict with CEO Sam Altman regarding the company's transition to a for-profit model.
- Musk previously sued OpenAI over restructuring plans, but later dropped the suit before filing a new complaint.
- OpenAI claims Musk is using his social media influence to conduct malicious campaigns against the company.
- A jury trial is set to start in spring 2026, following Musk's attempts to acquire OpenAI.
- OpenAI recently raised $40bn in funding to enhance its AI research and infrastructure.

items.title: Rematch packs five-a-side football with sweaty thrills
items.summary:
- Rematch is a new five-a-side football game emphasizing fast-paced, skill-driven gameplay with a focus on individual player control.
- Creative Director Pierre Tarno highlights the game's departure from traditional team strategies, favoring dynamic, player-focused actions instead.
- The game is set in a futuristic 2065, showcasing positive environmental themes and aiming to create a joyful multiplayer experience.
- Players can customize their avatars, including options for inclusivity with vitiligo selection and customizable prostheses.
- Rematch features an online-only format with a strong emphasis on teamwork and communication, drawing parallels to popular games like Overwatch and Rocket League.

items.title: Friday briefing: Has the campaign to get smartphones out of schools reached a tipping point?
My husband is always on his iPad. I miss him. How can I ask for screen-free time together? | Leading questions
items.summary:
- The husband frequently uses his iPad or phone, impacting family time.
- The writer feels resentment and wishes for screen-free quality time together.
- Suggestions include asking for specific activities to replace screen time and expressing love to encourage more connection.

items.title: Sledgehammer-wielding Musk critics smash up Tesla in London art project
items.summary:
- Critics of Elon Musk participated in a public art project where they smashed a disused Tesla Model S.
- The event was organized by the group Everyone Hates Elon to raise awareness about wealth inequality.
- Proceeds from the auction of the destroyed vehicle will be donated to food bank charities.
- Participants described the event as therapeutic and a way to express frustration towards billionaire influence.
- The event took place in London and included safety measures for participants.
- Tesla shares dropped 13% in early 2025 amid backlash against Musk's political actions.

items.title: Predictive policing has prejudice built in | Letters
Amazon’s satellite launch designed to compete with Musk’s Starlink cancelled
items.summary:
- Amazon's satellite launch for Project Kuiper was cancelled due to poor weather conditions, specifically cumulus clouds and strong winds.
- The launch was scheduled for 7pm (2300 GMT) from Cape Canaveral, Florida, but was deemed unsafe as cumulus clouds can trigger lightning strikes.
- Project Kuiper aims to position over 3,200 satellites in low Earth orbit to provide internet access globally, competing directly with SpaceX’s Starlink service.

items.title: Apple said to be flying iPhones from India to US to avoid Trump tariffs
items.summary:
- Apple is chartering cargo flights to transport iPhones from India to the US to evade Donald Trump’s tariffs.
- 600 tonnes of iPhones, approximately 1.5 million units, have been flown to the US since March.
- Trump’s threatened tariffs of 26% on Indian imports are currently on hold for three months.
- Import taxes from India under Trump’s measures remain at a reduced rate of 10%.
- Analysts warn that US tariffs on China could lead to significant price increases for iPhones.
- Apple aims for a 20% production increase at Indian plants by boosting workforce and Sunday operations.
- The Chennai plant produced 20 million iPhones last year, including the iPhone 15 and 16 models.
- If Apple redirects all production from India to the US, it could meet about 50% of American demand this year.
- Moving production to the US could result in iPhone costs soaring to $3,500.

items.title: The best power banks and battery packs for reliable charging on the go, tested
items.summary:
- Carrying a power bank is crucial for on-the-go charging of devices like smartphones and laptops.
- 10 models tested include brands like Belkin, Anker, and Cuktech.
- Power banks are suited for varying devices based on power output and compatibility.
- Best power bank overall: [Belkin BoostCharge Pro 3-port 20k](https://go.skimresources.com/?id=114047X1572903&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.argos.co.uk%2Fproduct%2F4073040&sref=https://www.theguardian.com/thefilter/2025/apr/10/best-power-banks-portable-chargers-battery-uk) priced at £79.99.
- Best portable power bank: [Anker Nano](https://go.skimresources.com/?id=114047X1572903&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.anker.com%2Fuk%2Fproducts%2Fa1653-usb-c-portable-charger-5000mah&sref=https://www.theguardian.com/thefilter/2025/apr/10/best-power-banks-portable-chargers-battery-uk) at £29.99.
- Best budget option: [Belkin BoostCharge 10k](https://go.skimresources.com/?id=114047X1572903&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.belkin.com%2Fuk%2Fp%2Fpower-bank-10k-with-integrated-cable%2FBPB021hqPK.html&sref=https://www.theguardian.com/thefilter/2025/apr/10/best-power-banks-portable-chargers-battery-uk) at £24.99.

items.title: Gerry Adams considers suing Meta over alleged use of his books to train AI
items.summary:
- Gerry Adams is contemplating legal action against Meta for allegedly using his books to train AI.
- Adams claims at least seven of his works, including his autobiography and a prison memoir, were used without permission.
- He joins a wider backlash against Meta, relating to its use of a database known as Library Genesis, which contains pirated material.
- Various authors have protested against Meta's practices, arguing that the company is violating copyright laws.
- A Meta spokesperson maintains that their usage of materials for AI training is compliant with existing laws.

items.title: Federal workers fear Musk’s ‘efficiency’ agency is using AI to spy on them: ‘They are omnipresent’
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Federal employees express concerns over surveillance measures being implemented by Elon Musk’s efficiency initiatives, fearing AI is being used to monitor them.
- A senior official at the Department of Veterans Affairs warned that virtual meetings could be recorded without notice.
- Staff members from various departments are reportedly using white noise machines to prevent eavesdropping amidst fears of AI scanning conversations for disloyalty or specific buzzwords.
- Recent reports detail a systemic culture of fear, exacerbated by recent layoffs and the rise of monitoring software across multiple agencies.
- The EPA has denied recording meetings but has been reported to use AI for monitoring communications. Employees are advised to be cautious about their private conversations.
- Various agencies have created an atmosphere of paranoia, with employees advised to act as if they are constantly being watched or recorded.

items.title: France to tighten mobile phone ban in middle schools
items.summary:
- France is tightening the ban on mobile phone use in middle schools for students aged 11 to 15, requiring devices to be stored in lockers or pouches for the entire school day starting September.
- Education Minister Élisabeth Borne emphasized the importance of separating children from screens for their wellbeing and academic success, citing positive effects from a previous ban.
- The new measure follows a pilot scheme that showed improved school atmospheres, and it's backed by studies indicating excessive screen time negatively impacts students' reading and success.
- There is a recommendation that children should not use smartphones until age 13 and should avoid social media until age 18.

items.title: AI avatar generator Synthesia does video footage deal with Shutterstock
items.summary:
- Synthesia has secured a licensing deal with Shutterstock to use its stock footage in developing AI avatars.
- The deal aims to enhance the realism of avatars by improving their expressions and body language.
- Synthesia will not use Shutterstock’s people as avatars but will utilize the footage to train AI on workplace interactions.
- The UK government is considering copyright law changes that impact AI firms' use of copyrighted materials without consent.

items.title: Black Mirror’s pessimism porn won’t lead us to a better future
items.summary:
* Black Mirror reflects modern technology narratives, often highlighting our fears and anxieties about the future.
* The show is critiqued for primarily endorsing a pessimistic view of technology, lacking exploration of its potential benefits.
* Dystopian narratives prevent creative thinking about a better future and can lead to harmful societal choices, as seen with GMO and nuclear energy debates.
* Historical examples illustrate how fear of technology can result in societal setbacks, contrary to positive outcomes offered by innovation.
* A call for a new narrative that balances caution with optimism, focusing on the possibilities of technology rather than solely its risks.

items.title: Apple MacBook Air M4 review: the laptop to beat, now cheaper
Energy demands from AI datacentres to quadruple by 2030, says report
items.summary:
- AI technology is expected to require nearly as much energy by 2030 as Japan uses today, with only half of the demand potentially sourced from renewables.
- Datacentre electricity demand is projected to more than double globally by 2030, driven mainly by AI, with dedicated AI datacentres' demand forecast to quadruple.
- One datacentre can consume as much electricity as 100,000 households, while some under construction may require 20 times more.
- Concerns about the climate impact of AI's energy demands have been deemed overstated, as AI could also enhance energy efficiency and reduce emissions.
- The rise of AI presents challenges for energy grids originally designed for fossil fuels, necessitating a redesign for renewables.
- Governments will need to manage the rapid growth of AI to mitigate severe impacts on energy systems and the environment.

items.title: More than 90% of schools in England ban mobile phone use, survey shows
Royal Mail trials postbox with parcel hatch, solar panels and barcode scanner
items.summary:
- Royal Mail introduces a solar-powered postbox with a barcode reader and a hatch for larger parcels.
- This design marks the first significant change in postbox design in over 175 years.
- The postbox allows customers to drop off barcoded packages and request proof of posting via the Royal Mail app.
- Currently, a trial is being conducted with five postboxes in Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire.
- Royal Mail plans to adapt thousands of postboxes due to the growing parcel trade, despite declining letter volumes.
- Royal Mail CEO Emma Gilthorpe emphasizes the need to evolve postboxes in response to changing consumer habits.
